Here in Milton, we value local! Why is it important to eat local?
1. It supports our farmers and keeps your dollar LOCAL
2. It is better for the environment since the food doesn't have to travel so far in planes, trains, and automobiles
3. Local food is picked at peak ripeness, meaning it contains the most nutrients it possibly can (and that it tastes amazing!). When food has to travel, it is picked prematurely to compensate for travel time.
If you visit our middle school cafeteria during lunch time look out for our local product signs to see what we are debuting for local products that day!

We try our hardest to create a healthy environment for our students every day. Here are some tips from the Coalition for Activity and Nutrition to Defeat Obesity that you can follow to raise a healthy eater:

1. Set regular meal and snack times
2. Be persistent, but not forceful. Continue to offer healthy foods, even if your children don't like them at first. Encourage your children to try new foods, but do not force them to eat.
3. Be a role model. Children often follow their parents' lead, so if you eat healthy, so will your kids.
4. Involve your kids. Let your kids help choose recipes, go shopping, and prepare meals.
5. Start with small portions. It is ok to have seconds if your child says they are still hungry, but start with small servings first.
6. Give positive rewards. Avoid using food as a reward. Instead, praise your child's good behavior with positive words, play time, or extra time with you

Healthy kids, healthy community!

post_text: Heard of Johnny Appleseed? He was the pioneer of the American apple! Although the 1,400 acres of orchards John Chapman grew were for cider apples (not edible like the ones of today), by spreading apples by seed he is responsible for evolutionarily creating the amazing variety of apples we now have hundreds of years later. As yesterday was Johnny Appleseed's birthday, we celebrated with cinnamon apple taste tests with elementary students today! YUM!
